lexUnit.name: catapult.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: hurl or launch with or as if with a catapult.

sentence.text: I catapulted the tiny beasts across the creek and into the mud on the far side so that I could have funerals .
Anything too technical might catapult him into orbit again .
Although official records of dioxins date from the middle of last century , it was an explosion at an Italian chemical plant in Seveso in 1976 that catapulted them into the public arena .

Warning that there was no single mechanism which would catapult Britain to economic strength , Mr Kinnock said : ` Research and development , transport and communications , science , education and training ; they are the priorities .
The three adults seemed to be catapulted from their seats as they ran out into the back yard .
Once our parents are dead , we are catapulted into becoming the older generation ourselves .
As discussed above there are assumed to be a number of willing Doom Divers ready and waiting to step forward and be catapulted into the air .
He swerved and avoided the worst of the impact , but was catapulted on to the bonnet of the car and then on to the pavement .
She saw the driver of the car being catapulted out onto his back .
Some were catapulted out of smashed windows , while others were trapped and had to be cut free .
The van spun off the road into a school fence and trainee decorator Wayne , of Marrick Road , Park End , was catapulted out of the rear doors .
Hillary was catapulted to stardom and his life has never been the same since .
It catapults grains of sand at passing ants in an attempt to knock them down into the pit and eat them .
On one occasion William catapulted a lump of metal into a classroom full of pupils and a girl was quite badly injured .
Divorce or the death of a husband is enough to catapult a middle-class white woman and her children into poverty .
This roller coaster catapults you over 75ft into the air , then plummets you back to earth at 60mph .
